facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1259 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1259 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 20, 1966 of Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in First Appeal No. 61 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1966 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in First Appeal No. 61 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant first appointed in 1934 as a police companystable in erstwhile State of Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in 1,934 first ap- pointed as a police companystable in the erstwhile State of Gwalior and was promoted in March 1945 to the post of a Sub- Inspector.

facts.text: Appellant promoted in March 1945 to post of Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: Gwalior and was promoted in March 1945 to the post of a Sub- Inspector. In May 1948, the rulers of Gwalior, Indore and certain other States formed, under a companyenant executed by them, a new State, called the United States of Madhya Bharat.

facts.text: In May 1948, rulers of Gwalior, Indore and other States formed United States of Madhya Bharat under covenant.

anchor.surface_text: In May 1948, the rulers of Gwalior, Indore and certain other States formed, under a companyenant executed by them, a new State, called the United States of Madhya Bharat. The appellant was allowed to work as a Sub- Inspector in the new State of Madhya Bharat, but his name was entered from the very beginning, that is from May 1948, in the list of provisionally absorbed servants, and remained so during all material times.

facts.text: Appellant allowed to work as Sub-Inspector in Madhya Bharat, name entered in list of provisionally absorbed servants from May 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was allowed to work as a Sub- Inspector in the new State of Madhya Bharat, but his name was entered from the very beginning, that is from May 1948, in the list of provisionally absorbed servants, and remained so during all material times. By a numberification, dated December 16, 1948, the Madhya Bharat Government published rules, called the Retrenchment Terms.

facts.text: Madhya Bharat Government published Retrenchment Terms by notification dated December 16, 1948, revised July 9, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification, dated December 16, 1948, the Madhya Bharat Government published rules, called the Retrenchment Terms. As revised by another numberification, dated July 9, 1949, these Retrenchment Terms so far as they are relevant for the purposes of this appeal read as under

facts.text: Appellant received retrenchment order from Deputy Inspector-General, Central Range, while working at Bhilsa as Sub-Inspector, for consistent bad record under category 2 of Retrenchment Terms.

anchor.surface_text: While the appellant was working at Bhilsa as the sub- inspector, he received an order signed by the Deputy Inspector-General, Central Range, to the effect that the appellant was retrenched. for companysistent bad record under retrenchment category 2 of the said Retrenchment Terms.

facts.text: Retrenchment order informed appellant of benefits of leave, pension etc. due under Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The order, however, informed the appellant that he would be given all the benefits of leave, pension etc. due to him under the Rules.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal before Inspector-General of Police against retrenchment order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the said order, the appellant filed an appeal before the Inspector-General of Police.

facts.text: Inspector-General issued notice to appellant to show cause why order should not be made absolute under categories 2, 4 and 7.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspector-General issued a numberice to the appellant to show cause why the said order should number be made absolute under category 2, as also under categories 4 and 7 of the said Retrenchment Terms.

facts.text: Inspector-General rejected appellant's appeal by order dated January 2, 1954, confirmed order under categories 2, 4 and 7.

anchor.surface_text: By his order, dated January 2, 1954, the Inspector-General rejected the appeal and companyfirmed the said order, also Under categories 4 and 7 of the said Terms, that is, besides the  ,round of a companysistently bad record, also, on the ground of, the appellant number possessing the minimum qualification prescribed for the post, and the ground that the appellant, for reasons companysidered adequate by the Government, companyld number be absorbed in the Madhya Bharat service.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court of Madhya Pradesh claiming order was removal by way of punishment attracting Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: Resort to departmental authorities for redress against the said order having failed, the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, pleading inter-alia that the impugned order amounted to removal by way of punishment which attracted Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition on October 22, 1959 on ground of delay.

anchor.surface_text: On October 22, 1959, the High Court dismissed the writ petition on the ground of delay.

facts.text: High Court observed that order was bad for failure to follow Art. 311 procedure on ground of consistent bad record.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless, the High Court went into the question whether the said order amounted to dismissal or removal and attracted Art. 311. ... The result is that the administration having gone into the question of. undersirability or companysistent badness of the record, was, under the law obliged to follow the procedure prescribed in Article 311. Having admittedly failed to do so,. the removal order, though ostensibly one of retrenchment, would be bad.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit in 1960 in Court of Additional District Judge, Indore for declaration that order bad under Art. 311 and for salary.

anchor.surface_text: In 1960, the appellant filed the suit, from which this appeal arises, in the Court of the Additional District Judge, Indore for a declaration that the said order was bad by reason of failure to hold an inquiry under Art. 311 and that he therefore companytinued to be in service and for a decree for the salary for the entire period.

facts.text: Trial Judge decreed the suit relying on High Court observations in writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge decreed the suit relying upon the aforesaid obser- vations of the High Court in the said writ petition.

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh filed appeal to High Court against trial court decree in First Appeal No. 61 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh thereupon filed an appeal before the High Court against the said judgment and decree. The Division Bench of the High Court, which heard the appeal, had on it companyncidently Krishnan, J., who also was one of the judges on the Bench which had earlier dismissed the appellants said writ petition in 1959.

facts.text: High Court allowed State's appeal and set aside trial court decree on ground that categories 4 and 7 valid even if category 2 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the States appeal and set aside the decree passed by the Trial Judge. This was done on the ground that in retrenching the appellant the State had two grounds  1  a companysistent bad record, and  2  the appellant number possessing the minimum educational qualification. There being thus two grounds, although the impugned order companyld number be supported by the first ground by reason of the failure to companyply with the provisions of Art. 31 1, the second ground was a good ground and being a separate ground, the impugned order, on the basis of that ground, was justified.

facts.text: Appellant did not possess minimum qualification prescribed for post of Sub-Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: So far as category 4 was companycerned, there can be numberdoubt that the appellant did number have the minimum educational qualification required for the post of a Sub-Inspector.

facts.text: Appellant fell under category 7 as could not be absorbed for reasons considered adequate by Government.

anchor.surface_text: Since that was so, he would also fall in category No. 7, that is, as a person who companyld number, for reasons companysidered adequate by the Government, be absorbed in the service of the new State.

facts.text: Retrenchment Terms had effect from July 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: These orders shall have effect from the 1st of July, 1948.

facts.text: Appellant was permanent servant of erstwhile Gwalior State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, without doubt, was a permanent servant of the erstwhile Gwalior State and vis-a-vis that State, was, therefore, entitled to all the rights obtainable under the law of that State, whatever such rights there were thereunder.

facts.text: Terms of covenant under which Gwalior acceded not placed before courts.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the companyenant were number placed before us, number before the High Court.

facts.text: Retrenchment Terms based on Mohan Rau Committee recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: After a careful companysideration of the Mohan Rau Committees recommendations regarding the retrench- ment of surplus staff of the acceding States of the Madhya Bharat Union and companypensation terms to be offered to such staff, the Government of Madhya Bharat have been pleased to sanction the following principles

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the States appeal and set aside the decree passed by the Trial Judge. This was done on the ground that in retrenching the appellant the State had two grounds  1  a consistent bad record, and  2  the appellant not possessing the minimum educational qualification. There being thus two grounds, although the impugned order could not be supported by the first ground by reason of the failure to comply with the provisions of Art. 31 1, the second ground was a good ground and being a separate ground, the impugned order, on the basis of that ground, was justified.

concepts.interpretation: High Court held Art. 311 non-compliance on one ground irrelevant as order sustainable on other ground.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-State had relied upon categories 2, 4 and 7, as grounds for the impugned order. So far as category 4 was concerned, there can be no doubt that the appellant did not have the minimum educational qualification required for the post of a Sub-Inspector.

holdings.text: The impugned order did not amount to dismissal or removal by way of punishment attracting Art. 311 as the appellant was surplus provisionally absorbed staff from acceding State, not an employee of the new State of Madhya Bharat, and non-absorption under Retrenchment Terms was not removal from service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, without doubt, was a permanent servant of the erstwhile Gwalior State and vis-a-vis that State, was, therefore, entitled to all the rights obtainable under the law of that State, whatever such rights there were thereunder. On the accession of Gwalior State to the United States of Madhya Bharat, his position, however, totally changed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrenchment Terms governed selection for absorption of surplus ex-employees of acceding States; appellant provisionally employed pending absorption decision; categories identified those not to be absorbed; hence not yet employees of new State to whom Art. 311 applies.

holdings.text: The impugned retrenchment order was valid and sustainable on categories 4 and 7 (lack of minimum qualification and non-absorbability for adequate reasons) which were independent objective grounds, even assuming category 2 (consistent bad record) unavailable due to Art. 311 non-compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-State had relied upon categories 2, 4 and 7, as grounds for the impugned order. So far as category 4 was concerned, there can be no doubt that the appellant did not have the minimum educational qualification required for the post of a Sub-Inspector. Since that was so, he would also fall in category No. 7,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categories 4 and 7 involve objective tests verifiable on facts (appellant lacked qualification, hence non-absorbable); unlike subjective satisfaction cases, failure of one objective ground does not vitiate order if others suffice.
